bestBHT.bht: Confessing that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh is a decisive test to discern the Spirit of God. Teachers claiming inspiration by the Holy Spirit are measured by this confession, aligning themselves with God and truth. This acknowledgment safeguards against deception, ensuring that their doctrine is of God. Those who proclaim this truth are to be regarded, as they carry the truth and are on the side of God and truth.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Hereby know . . . the Spirit of God—whether he be, or not, in those teachers professing to be moved by Him.
Every spirit—that is, Every teacher claiming inspiration by the HOLY SPIRIT.

Jesus Christ is come in the flesh—a twofold truth confessed, that Jesus is the Christ, and that He is come in the flesh ('clothed with flesh': not with a mere seeming humanity, as the Docetæ afterwards taught).
Albert Barnes: You may discern who are actuated by the Spirit of God.
If they did not do this, it would be decisive in regard to their character and claims.
The fact that there was a real incarnation is essential to all just views of the atonement.
Marvin Vincent: That Jesus Christ is come in the flesh [ιησουν χριστον εν σαρκι εληλυθοτα].
John Calvin: As long then as we abide in Christ, there is safety; but when we depart from him, faith is lost, and all truth is rendered void.

By saying that he came in the flesh, he means that by putting on flesh, he became a real man, of the same nature with us, that he might become our brother, except that he was free from every sin and corruption.

The Apostle then meant this, that since the knowledge of Christ includes the sum and substance of the doctrine respecting true religion, our eyes ought to be directed to and fixed on that, so that we may not be deceived.
Archibald T. Robertson: The test of 'the Spirit of God' here alone in this Epistle, save verse 1 John 4:13. With the clamour of voices then and now this is important."
The predicate participle describes Jesus as already come in the flesh (his actual humanity, not a phantom body as the Docetic Gnostics held)."
A like test is proposed by Paul for confessing the deity of Jesus Christ in 1 Corinthians 12:3 and for the Incarnation and Resurrection of Jesus in Romans 10:6-10.
John Gill: Every spirit that confesseth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh, is of God; or of the Spirit of God; that is, every doctrine which carries this truth in it.
Every man that owns, and professes, and publishes this doctrine concerning Christ, is on the side of God and truth.
Whoever brings these truths with him, and preaches them, he is, so far as he does so, on the side of God and truth, and to be regarded.
John Wesley: Which confesseth — Both with heart and voice.
Jesus Christ, who is come in the flesh, is of God — This his coming presupposes, contains, and draws after it, the whole doctrine of Christ.
